notebook.markdown: # Conda
> Disclaimer: This post has been translated to English using a machine translation model. Please, let me know if you find any mistakes.

When working in data science, artificial intelligence, deep learning, or whatever you want to call it, we are going to work on several projects. And in some of them, you might need to install, for example, version 11.6 of CUDA and in others, version 11.8. In such cases, they will advise you, never fight with CUDA, it always wins.
Therefore, it's best to create separate environments for each project. This way, you can install whatever you want in each environment and not globally. And thus, you won't have issues with library version incompatibilities.
To create Python environments, the default is `venv`, which are its virtual environments. However, I recommend you use `conda` to create your virtual environments, as it not only creates virtual environments but is also a package manager, and it is a better package manager than `pip`. This is not an explanatory post on `conda`, so you won't find how to install it or how to use it. It's a post that talks about the advantages of using `conda` and also using `mamba` (which we will explain later).
I will create three distinct conda environments, one will be called `pip_env`, another `conda_env`, and the other `mamba_env`.
## Conda vs PIP
### pip_env
I am going to create a new environment called `pip_env`
In the `pip_env` environment, I will install `pandas`
notebook.output_code: Collecting pandas Using cached pandas-2.0.1-cp310-cp310-manylinux_2_17_x86_64.manylinux2014_x86_64.whl (12.3 MB) Requirement already satisfied: numpy>=1.21.0 in /home/wallabot/miniconda3/envs/pip_env/lib/python3.10/site-packages (from pandas) (1.24.3) Requirement already satisfied: python-dateutil>=2.8.2 in /home/wallabot/miniconda3/envs/pip_env/lib/python3.10/site-packages (from pandas) (2.8.2) Requirement already satisfied: pytz>=2020.1 in /home/wallabot/miniconda3/envs/pip_env/lib/python3.10/site-packages (from pandas) (2023.3) Requirement already satisfied: tzdata>=2022.1 in /home/wallabot/miniconda3/envs/pip_env/lib/python3.10/site-packages (from pandas) (2023.3) Requirement already satisfied: six>=1.5 in /home/wallabot/miniconda3/envs/pip_env/lib/python3.10/site-packages (from python-dateutil>=2.8.2->pandas) (1.16.0) Installing collected packages: pandas Successfully installed pandas-2.0.1
notebook.markdown: As can be seen in the output when installing `pandas`, it depends on `numpy`, so it installs it in version `1.24.3`. But if for some reason we need `numpy` in version `1.19`, if we try to install it, we will get an error.
notebook.output_code:

notebook.markdown: We got an error, and if we check which version of `numpy` we have, we see that we are still on `1.24.3`
notebook.input_code: # pip_env import numpy as np np.__version__
notebook.markdown: And we check which version of `pandas` we have
notebook.input_code: # pip_env import pandas as pd pd.__version__
notebook.markdown: ### conda_env
To resolve this conflict, we can use `conda`, I create a new environment called `conda_env`
And now we tell it that we want to install `numpy` version `1.19` and `pandas`, and `conda` will find a way to do it.
notebook.output_code:
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: done

package | build ---------------------------|----------------- ca-certificates-2023.01.10 | h06a4308_0 120 KB certifi-2021.5.30 | py36h06a4308_0 139 KB intel-openmp-2022.1.0 | h9e868ea_3769 4.5 MB mkl-2020.2 | 256 138.3 MB mkl-service-2.3.0 | py36he8ac12f_0 52 KB mkl_fft-1.3.0 | py36h54f3939_0 170 KB mkl_random-1.1.1 | py36h0573a6f_0 327 KB numpy-1.19.2 | py36h54aff64_0 22 KB numpy-base-1.19.2 | py36hfa32c7d_0 4.1 MB pandas-1.1.5 | py36ha9443f7_0 8.2 MB pytz-2021.3 | pyhd3eb1b0_0 171 KB ------------------------------------------------------------ Total: 156.1 MB ... Preparing transaction: done Verifying transaction: done Executing transaction: done
notebook.markdown: It seems that he has managed it, let's see
notebook.input_code: # conda_env import numpy as np np.__version__
# conda_env import pandas as pd pd.__version__
notebook.markdown: We see that you were able to install both, but to resolve the conflicts you installed `pandas` in version `1.1.5`, instead of version `2.0.1` that was installed by `pip`.
## Mamba vs Conda

Now that we have seen that conda is better at resolving conflicts, let's look at the difference between using `mamba` and `conda`. As we have seen, `conda` is very good at resolving conflicts, but it has the problem of being slow when installing packages, as it installs dependencies in series, one after another. Thanks to `mamba`, we will have the same benefits of `conda`, only the dependencies will be installed in parallel, making use of the cores we have on our micro.
### conda_env
We are going to stay in the `conda_env` and we are going to see how long it takes to install `pytorch`. By putting `time` before a command, we can see how long it takes to execute.
notebook.input_code: # conda_env !time conda install -y pytorch torchvision torchaudio pytorch-cuda=11.8 -c pytorch -c nvidia
notebook.output_code:

notebook.markdown: We see that it took 294.42 seconds, about 4.9 minutes, almost 5 minutes.
### mamba_env
Now we are going to reinstall `pytorch`, but with `mamba`. First, we create an environment called `mamba_env`
To install `mamba`, download it from [mambaforge](https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge#mambaforge) and install it.
Now we reinstall `pytorch` in `mamba_env`
notebook.input_code: # mamba_env !time mamba install -y pytorch torchvision torchaudio pytorch-cuda=11.8 -c pytorch -c nvidia
notebook.output_code:

notebook.markdown: Now it took 121.61 seconds, about 2 minutes. Less than half the time compared to `conda`.
## Create an environment from a file

We might want to create an environment with a specific list of packages, so we can pass a file to conda to create the environment with those packages. To do this, we create a file called `environment.yml` with content like the following
```yml name: environment_from_file channels: - defaults - conda-forge - pytorch - nvidia dependencies: - python=3.11 - cudatoolkit=11.8 - pytorch=2.2.1 - torchaudio- torchvision - pip - pip: - transformers ```
As we can see, the name of the environment is specified, the channels we are going to use, the packages with their versions that we are going to install through Conda, and the packages we are going to install through Pip. Now we tell Conda to create the environment with those packages.
```bash conda env create -f environment.yml ```
We create the file
notebook.input_code: !touch environment.yml \ && echo "name: entorno_desde_archivo" >> environment.yml \ && echo "channels:" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - defaults" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - conda-forge" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - pytorch" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - nvidia" >> environment.yml \ && echo "dependencies:" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - python=3.11" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - cudatoolkit=11.8" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - pytorch=2.2.1" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - torchaudio" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - torchvision" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - pip" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - pip:" >> environment.yml \ && echo " - transformers" >> environment.yml
notebook.markdown: Now that we have the file, we can create the custom environment
## Install packages from a file

Another thing we can do is have a list of packages that we want to install. To install all of them at once, we can create a file called `requirements.yml` with content like the following
```txt channels: - conda-forge dependencies: - pandas==2.2.1 - matplotlib==3.8.3 ```
And now we tell Conda to install those packages
```bash conda install --file requirements.yml ```
Now that we have the file, we install the packages
